senses.de: The state of being responsible for something, especially by law
senses.ex: The company is under no legal liability to compensate you

Tips.title: Legal Significance
Tips.description: In law, liability comes with consequences. It means owing a duty that, if unmet, can lead to lawsuits or penalties.
Tips.example: If they prove negligence, you might face legal liability.

Tips.title: Not Always Negative
Tips.description: 'Liability' sounds negative but in legal terms, it simply refers to a bound duty or obligation, not a fault.
Tips.example: As a director, she accepted her liability for the company's actions.

Tips.title: Beyond Money
Tips.description: Liability isn't just about financial responsibilities; it covers any legal responsibility, like safety obligations.
Tips.example: The landlord has liability for tenant's safety.

senses.de: A person or thing whose presence or behavior is likely to cause embarrassment or put one at a disadvantage
senses.ex: Your erratic attendance could become a liability

Tips.title: Negative Connotation
Tips.description: 'Liability' can imply that someone or something is a burden or problem in non-legal contexts.
Tips.example: His lack of experience is a liability to the team.

Tips.title: Comparative Assessment
Tips.description: When weighing options, being 'a liability' means it may have more disadvantages than advantages.
Tips.example: While skilled, his short temper is a liability.

senses.de: The amount of money that a company or person owes to others
senses.ex: The company has liabilities of $10 million

Tips.title: Not Always Debt
Tips.description: In finance, liabilities are not just loans; they include wages payable, taxes owed, and accounts payable.
Tips.example: The balance sheet listed taxes as the largest liability.

Tips.title: Balance Sheet Term
Tips.description: Liability is a key term in balance sheets, and is crucial for understanding a company's financial health.
Tips.example: Accountants differentiate between short-term and long-term liabilities.

Tips.title: Business Structure
Tips.description: Certain business types, like limited liability companies, are named after the concept to describe owners' financial risk.
Tips.example: He favored the limited liability structure to protect personal assets.

senses.de: An obligation, such as a legal or monetary debt
senses.ex: He got into a liability of $50000 due to credit card loans

Tips.title: Legal Commitments
Tips.description: Liabilities as obligations can happen out of legal requirements, such as a court order to pay alimony.
Tips.example: Failure to fulfill his liability for alimony could result in legal action.

Tips.title: Personal Financial Impact
Tips.description: Personal liabilities affect your credit score and borrowing capacity, reflecting your debt responsibilities.
Tips.example: His car loan is his biggest personal liability.

Accountability.wordDefinition:
Accountability means being answerable for your actions or decisions. It implies taking responsibility for your actions and their consequences.

Accountability is about taking responsibility for your actions, while liability is about legal responsibility for the consequences of your actions.

Burden.wordDefinition:
Burden refers to something that is difficult or unpleasant to deal with.

It can be a physical or emotional weight that is carried by someone or something. For example, a heavy workload can be a burden.

A burden is something that causes hardship, while a liability is something that involves legal or moral responsibility.

Charge.wordDefinition:
Charge refers to the action of making someone pay for something or imposing a responsibility on them. For example, if you use your credit card, you may be charged interest on the balance.

In legal terms, you may be charged with a crime if you break the law.

Charge usually refers to the act of making payment or imposing a responsibility, while liability refers to being held responsible for any loss or damage incurred.

Debt.wordDefinition:
Debt is money that one person or entity owes to another person or entity. For example, if you borrow $50 from a friend, you have a debt of $50 to repay.

It can include debts, but it can also include other things like legal obligations or contractual commitments. For example, a company may have a liability to pay employee salaries or a liability to provide certain services to customers.

Debt is a specific type of liability that refers to money owed, while liability is a broader term that encompasses broader financial obligations.

Duty.wordDefinition:
Duty refers to a responsibility or obligation that a person has to do something, either because of their job or position or because of moral or ethical principles.

For example, a doctor has a duty to provide medical care to their patients.

In essence, duty refers to a sense of obligation or responsibility, while liability refers to legal responsibility for something that has gone wrong.

Duty is applicable to a wide range of situations, both personal and professional, while liability is typically only applicable in legal matters.

Encumbrance.wordDefinition:
Encumbrance refers to any legal claim or burden on a property, such as a mortgage or lien. It limits the ownership rights of the property owner.

Encumbrances can also refer to a restriction or limitation on a property, such as an easement or zoning regulation.

Encumbrance refers to a legal claim on a property, while liability refers to a legal responsibility for something.

Encumbrances are typically applicable in real estate transactions, while liabilities can arise in various legal and financial contexts.

Obligation.wordDefinition:
Obligation refers to a duty or responsibility to do something, typically because of a moral or legal duty. If you have an obligation to do something, it means you must do it, but it doesn't necessarily mean you will be legally held accountable if you don't.

So in short, liability is about legal responsibility, while obligation is about moral or legal duty to do something.

Onus.wordDefinition:
Liability refers to being legally responsible for something, such as a debt or damages caused to someone or something. Onus refers to a responsibility or duty to do something, often implying a moral obligation rather than a legal one.

If someone witnesses a dangerous situation and doesn't speak up or take action, there may be an onus on that person to report it or do something to prevent harm.

Liability is more associated with legal or financial obligations, while onus is more associated with ethical or personal responsibilities.

Responsibility.wordDefinition:
Responsibility refers to the duty or obligation to do something. It is more about taking ownership and being accountable for one's actions.

For example, a student has the responsibility to turn in their homework on time, which may not have legal or financial consequences but still has consequences in terms of their academic performance.

Both words can be applicable in various contexts, but liability is usually associated with legal and financial consequences, while responsibility is more related to moral and personal obligations.

quotes.Text: The great liability of the engineer compared to men of other professions is that his works are out in the open where all can see them. His acts, step by step, are in hard substance. He cannot bury his mistakes in the grave like the doctors. He cannot argue them into thin air or blame the judge like the lawyers.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Herbert Hoover

quotes.Text: One of my favorite things to do is formulate powers for a character, then come up with their corresponding weaknesses and liabilities. And I delight in world-building: melding the supernatural with the natural, then tweaking and polishing until it feels organic.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Kresley Cole

quotes.Text: Now is not the time to give greater protections to pharmaceutical companies that put unsafe drugs like Vioxx on the market. Such protections have nothing to do with the liability insurance crisis facing doctors and should be stripped from this bill.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Dennis Cardoza

quotes.Text: Banks are so protected from liability they would have to really do something that was their mistake in order for them to be liable for it. Banks don't look at signatures. They're processing millions of checks and they have very little liability.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Frank Abagnale

quotes.Text: The thing that forced me to think about my retirement was that I had played my cricket with honour and distinction, and I did not want to put myself in a position where I was considered a liability or unwanted by the selectors.
quotes.Title: Pakistani Coach
quotes.Name: Inzamam-ul-Haq

quotes.Text: Tax increases slow economic growth. Why would you raise taxes? We need to reform spending, the tens of trillions of unfunded liabilities can never be funded by tax increases, that can only be fixed by reducing spending.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Grover Norquist

quotes.Text: The public should know that the liability issues here have yet to be resolved, or even raised. If you're a farmer and you're growing a genetically engineering food crop, those genes are going to flow to the other farm.
quotes.Title: American Economist
quotes.Name: Jeremy Rifkin

quotes.Text: Just like every other industry, the firearms industry can in fact be sued - a far cry from being immune or 'wholly protected' of any liability.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Katie Pavlich

quotes.Text: President Trump's greatest political liabilities revolve around questions of personality and character.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Michael J. Knowles

quotes.Text: Liability does apply with respect to the amount of the oil spill.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Ken Salazar
